awd_titl_txt: Studies of Singularities, Black Holes, and Gravitational Radiation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study two aspects of gravity: gravitational collapse and gravitational radiation.  When an object's gravity becomes strong enough to trap light, the object becomes a black hole.  Inside the black hole the object continues to become smaller and smaller under the influence of its own gravity until it becomes a point with infinite density and infinite gravitational field called a singularity.  This project involves working out the properties of the singularities formed in gravitational collapse, and in particular the forces felt by any observer who approaches the singularity. Just as the electric currents in a radio transmitter make radio waves, so moving masses make gravitational waves.  One of the most exciting recent developments in physics is the direct detection of these gravitational waves using huge laser interferometers as the detectors.  One interesting aspect of gravitational radiation is something called gravitational wave memory: even after the wave has passed, there is a permanent change in the gravitational wave detector.  This project will study the causes and properties of this gravitational wave memory.

Gravitational collapse results in the formation of black holes and spacetime singularities, and the emission of gravitational radiation. This project will study all of these aspects of gravitational collapse, and in particular will concentrate on the approach to the singularity, gravitational wave memory, and critical behavior at the threshold of black hole formation.  The project will study the formation of small scale structure in the approach to the generic spacelike singularity.  In addition, simulations will be done of the collapse of vacuum, asymptotically flat spacetimes in order to test the conjecture that both strong spacelike singularities and weak null singularities form in this case. In previous work, this group developed a treatment of gravitational wave memory that uses a perturbative approach in which the Weyl tensor is the basic variable and thus has manifest gauge invariance in first order perturbation theory.  This project will extend this approach to treat the memory of gravitational radiation (Christodoulou memory) using second order perturbation theory. Simulations will be performed of critical gravitational collapse to develop a better understanding of the Choptuik critical solution, in particular the structure inside the horizon of the slightly supercritical case, and the spacetime near the Cauchy horizon for the critical solution.  Einstein-Aether theory will be studied to see whether some of its black hole solutions are unstable.  In addition an initial value formulation of this theory will be developed for the general case of no symmetry.

por.por_cntn:
This project  studied spacetime singularties and gravitational waves.  Spacetime singularities are regions of extremely large tidal force that occur inside black holes and at the Big Bang at the begining of the universe.  The porject included computer simulations to examine the behavior of these singularities.  These simulations show that the behaivor of spacetime actually becomes simpler as the singularity is approached and can be described by simple formulas.

 

Gravitational waves stretch and squeeze space.  Gravitational wave memory is a residual stretch and squeeze of space that remains even after the gravitational wave is passed. The project considers an analog of gravitational wave memory in the behavior of electromagnetic waves. A result of the project is an explanation of  the main properties of both gravitational wave memory and its electromagnetic analog using only the wave equation, which is the simple mathematical description of sound waves, water waves, and other wave phenomena. 

 

The project considers a scenario to account for small mass black holes (sometimes known as "mass gap objects") found in recent gravitational wave detections.  In this scenario the small black hols is the outcome of a so-called Thorne-Zykow object, which is a neutron star in the core of a red giant star. In this scenario, the small balck hole is formed when the neutrton star absorbs enough material from the red giant that it undergoes gravitational collapse.

 

Associated with the project was the writiing of a mathematics popularization titled "X marks the spot" which explains various aspects of mathematics from the points of view of both mathematicians and  the users of mathematics.
